(7) Korfmacher WA et al; Environ Sci Technol 14: 1094-9 (1980)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), fluoranthene, which has a vapor pressure of 9.22X10-6 mm Hg at 25 °C(2), will exist in both the vapor and particulate phases in the ambient atmosphere. Vapor-phase fluoranthene is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be about 8 hours(SRC) calculated from its rate constant of 5.0X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(3). Particulate-phase fluoranthene may be physically removed from the air by wet and dry deposition(SRC). The atmospheric lifetime of vapor-phase fluoranthene due to reaction with nitrate radicals has been calculated as approximately 85 days(4). Fluoranthene absorbs UV light at wavelengths >290 nm(5) and, therefore, may be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC). The photolytic half-life of fluoranthene adsorbed to silica, alumina, fly ash, and carbon black substrates were measured as 74, 23, 44, and >1,000 hours, respectively, following irradiation with a 400 watt mercury lamp(6). Fluoranthene is found both in the free and adsorbed state in both the aqueous and atmospheric compartments and photodegradation is usually different in the sorbed state(7).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) Cerniglia CE; Biodegradation 3: 351-68 (1992)
(2) Mueller JG et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 57: 1277-85 (1991)
(3) Petrasek AC et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 55: 1286-96 (1983)
(4) Rouse JD et al; Crit Rev Environ Sci Technol 24: 325-70 (1994)
(5) Tabak HH et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 53: 1503-18 (1981)
(6) van Luin AB, van Starkenburg W; Wat Sci Tech 17: 843-53 (1984)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Laboratory studies show that fluoranthene can be substantially mineralized in sediments containing indigenous microorganisms; major metabolites include fluoranthene trans-2,3-dihydrodiol, and 8 and 9-hydroxyfluoranthene trans-2,3-dihydrodiols(1). In shake flask studies, an initial fluoranthene concentration of 16.2 ug/mL was reduced to 7.6 ug/mL following 2 weeks incubation in contaminated groundwater from the American Creosote Works Superfund site, Pensacola, FL(2). In a pilot wastewater treatment plant, no fluoranthene was lost due to biodegradation(3). The presence of the anionic surfactant SDS was found to enhance the biodegradation of fluoranthene(4). Mixed results were reported in a static biodegradability test employing a domestic wastewater inoculum where 100% and 0% of the fluoranthene was degraded in four successive weekly subcultures at concentrations of 5 and 10 mg/L, respectively(5). Fluoranthene removal from the waste water of six municipal waste water treatment plants along the Rhine River in The Netherlands avgd 95%(6).

Reference: (1) Sims RC, Overcash MC; Res Rev 88: 1-68 (1983)
(2) Gardner WS et al; Water Air Soil Pollut 11: 339-47 (1979)
(3) Groenewegen D, Stolp H; Zentrablat Bakteriol Parasitenkd Infektionskr Hyg Abt 1: Orig Reike B 162: 225-32 (1976)
(4) Bossert I et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 47: 763-7 (1984)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: When crude oil enriched with fluoranthene was incubated with coastal sediment in a flowing seawater system, 1.9%-2.4% of the chemical was removed per week translating to a half-life of 143-182 days(1,2) or a degradation rate of 2 ng/g-soil per hour at a concn of 10 ug/g(1). Microbial degradation was more rapid in upper surfaces than in lower layers of sediment and greatest where the sediment grain size was largest(2). When percolated through a soil column in a mixture of polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), fluoranthene degraded with a half-life of 44 days(1,3). When 7 applications of polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbon-containing oily sludge was amended to soil over a two year period and then monitored for an additional year and a half, the fluoranthene residue in the soil at the end of the 2 year ammendation period was decreased by 39% in the following year and a half(6). In the sludge ammendation experiment, 4.7% of the applied fluoranthene remained after 3 1/2 years(4).

Reference: (1) Coover MP, Sims RC; Haz Waste Haz Mat 4: 69-82 (1987)
(2) Keck J et al; Wat Res 23: 1467-76 (1989)
(3) Kincannon DF, Lin YS; Proc Ind Waste Conf 40: 607-19 (1985)
(4) Loehr RC, Webster MT; J Soil Contam 5: 361-83 (1996)
(5) Park KS et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 9: 187-95 (1990)
(6) Wild SR, Jones KC; Environ Toxicol Chem 12: 5-12 (1993)
(7) Wild SR et al; pp. 457-62 in Contaminated Soil '90. Arendt F et al, eds. The Netherlands: Kluwer Academic Pub (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Seventy-one and 15% of an initial concentration of 400 ug/g fluoranthene remained after 240 days in an unacclimated agricultural sandy loam soil incubated at 20 and 30 °C, respectively; corresponding half-lives were estimated to be about 440 and 140 days(1). The half-life of fluoranthene in Kidman sandy loam soil was determined to be 26 days (oil refinery waste on soil), 440 days (synthetic mixture on soil), 74 days (1% creosote on soil), and 377 days (single constituents)(2). The half-life of fluoranthene in a wood preserving sludge soil was determined to be 91 days, from an initial concentration of 1200 mg/kg and a final concentration of 30 mg/kg after 287 days(3). The half-life of fluoranthene in a sludge-amended soil and in a spiked soil was reported to be 110 and 16 days, respectively(4). The degradation half-life for fluoranthene applied to Kidman sandy loam and McLaurin sandy loam was determined to be 377 days and 268 days, respectively(5). A study in which polyaromatic hydrocarbon contaminated sludge was applied to 4 soil samples collected in Lancaster, England resulted in biodegradation half-lives of 110, 184, 143, and 110 days for fluoranthene(6). A long term field study of the application of sewage sludge to soil at Luddington and Lee Valley, UK, resulted in average biodegradation half-lives of 7.8 and 3.1 years, respectively, for fluoranthene(7).

Reference: (1) Soli G; Hydrocarbon-oxidizing bacteria and their possible use as controlling agents of oil pollution in the ocean. NTIS AD-763 655. Naval Weapons Ctr China Lake CA (1973)
(2) Patterson JW, Kodukala PS; Chem Eng Prog 77: 48-55 (1981)

StringWithMarkup.String: PURE CULTURE: It has been shown that several bacterial strains isolated from the marine environment(1) and sewage(2) are capable of degrading fluoranthene.

Reference: (1) Kirk PWW, Lester JN; Environ Technol 12: 13-20 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: ANAEROBIC: Anaerobic sludge digestion over a period of 32 days was found to have no statistically significant effect on the concn of fluoranthene(1).

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) Atkinson R; J Phys Chem Ref Data (1989)
(2) Atkinson R, Arey J; Environ Health Per 102: 117-26 (1994)
(3) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 7-4, 7-5 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of fluoranthene with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been measured as 5.0X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 8 hours at an atmospheric concn of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(1). The atmospheric lifetime of vapor-phase fluoranthene due to reaction with nitrate radicals has been calculated as approximately 85 days(2). Fluoranthene is not expected to undergo hydrolysis in the environment due to the lack of hydrolyzable functional groups(3).

Reference: (1) Yamasaki H et al; Environ Sci Technol 16: 189-94 (1982)
(2) Keller CD, Bidleman TF; Atmos Environ 18: 837-45 (1984)

StringWithMarkup.String: The fraction of fluoranthene adsorbed to particulate matter in the atmosphere follows a Langmuir adsorption curve, being a function of suspended particle concentration and with a greater fraction of the chemical being in the vapor phase at higher temperature(1,2). During the year, between 1 and 23% of the fluoranthene was sorbed to particulate matter in Osaka, Japan(1).

Reference: (1) IARC; Polynuclear Aromatic Compounds. Part I. Chemical environ and experimental data. 32: 355-7 (1983)
(2) Sims RC, Overcash MR; Res Rev 88: 1-68 (1983)
(3) Korfmacher WA et al; Environ Sci Technol 14: 1094-9 (1980)
(4) Santodonato J et al; pp. 77-176 in Health and Ecological Assessment of Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons. Park Forest South,IL: Pathotox Publ Inc (1980)

StringWithMarkup.String: Fluoranthene absorbs solar radiation strongly and thereby can undergo direct photolysis(1,2). Polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons also photodecompose in the atmosphere by reaction with ozone, other oxidants, nitrogen oxides, and sulfur oxides while singlet oxygen is considered to be the major oxidant species in water(2). Fluoranthene is found both in the free and adsorbed state in both the aqueous and atmospheric compartments and photodegradation is usually different in the sorbed state. No significant degradation was observed when fluoranthene vapor adsorbed on coal fly ash from the electrostatic precipitator of a power plant was irradiated for 3.3 hr using a xexon lamp(3). When filters containing pure fluoranthene were exposed to air and synthetic smog (1 hr exposure equivalent of 100 hr exposure to natural smog), 20 and 24% of the cmpd decomposed in air in 48 hr in darkness or light, respectively. 59% was lost in 1 hr when exposed to smog and light(4). When filters containing fluoranthene sorbed on combustion particules were exposed, 4% of the compound was lost in 48 hrs in air and light while 59% was lost in 1 hr exposed to synthetic smog and light(4). Therefore, it would appear that sorbed fluoranthene is less reactive than the free vapor in air but equally reactive in photochemical smog(4). It should be noted that sorption on certain types of surfaces (eg silica gel) greatly enhances photodecomposition(2). When particulate matter from air was analyzed immediately and after being stored in a sealed envelope, it was found that 37% and 92% of the fluoranthene was lost in storage after 3 wks and 1 yr, respectively(2).

Reference: (1) Zepp RG, Schlotzhauer PF; pp. 141-58 in Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons; Ann Arbor Sci Publ Jones PW, Leber eds; Ann Arbor MI (1979)
(2) Zepp RG, Schlotzhauer PF; Environ Sci Technol 17: 462-8 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: In water, the half-life resulting from direct photolysis of fluoranthene in near surface waters exposed to sunlight (latitude 4 deg N, midday, midsummer) is calculated to be 21 hrs(1). If the water body is deep or turbid, the sunlight is attenuated. For example, in a well mixed body of water 5 m deep that contained sediment of 20 mg/1, the half-life is increased to 160 hrs if one does not take partitioning to particulate matter into account and 200 hrs if one does(1). Photolysis of polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons in nonpolar organic solvents are typically 10-100 times less than in water(1). Sorption onto green and blue green algae photosensitizes the degradation of fluoranthene(2). In the presence of algae at a concentration of 1-10 mg/1 chlorophyll, the photodegradation rate is increased by a factor of 6.6-11(2).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) Burkhard LP et al; Chemosphere 29: 141-53 (1994)
(2) Spehar RL et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 52: 1703-74 (1980)
(3) Lee RF et al; Environ Sci Technol 12: 832-38 (1978)
(4) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
(5) Santodonato J et al; in Health and Ecological Assessment of Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons; Lee SD, Grant L eds., Park Forest South IL: Pathotox Publ (1981)

(6) Anderson JW et al; Sources, Fates, and Effects of Aromatic Hydrocarbons in the Alaskan Marine Environment with Recommendations for Monitoring Strategies. NTIS PB86-168-291/AS. Washington,DC: USEPA (1986)
(7) Bayona JM et al; Chemosphere 23: 313-26 (1991)
(8) Eadie BJ et al; Chemosphere 11: 847-58 (1982)
(9) Carlson RM et al; Implications to the Aquatic Environ of Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons Liberated from Northern Great Plains Coal; USEPA-600/3-79-093 (1979)

StringWithMarkup.String: The BCF of fluoranthene in sunfish was determined to range between 2,640-6,110(1). In a 21 day bioconcentration test in a flow through tank, the log BCF in rainbow trout was 2.58 (BCF = 380)(2). A 28 day experiment in a flow through tank detected a log BCF of 3.60 (BCF = 3,981) after 7 days in fathead minnows; depuration occurred in 2 days(3). According to a classification scheme(4), the BCF values in sunfish, rainbow trout and fathead minnows suggest that the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high to very high(SRC). However, it may not bioconcentrate in aquatic organisms which contain microsomal oxidase, such as fish, as this enzyme enables the rapid metabolism of certain polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons(5). The BCF for fluoranthene in the clam Crassostrea virginica was 10,000 from 8 days exposure to 0.004 ppm fluoranthene via the overlying water column(6). Bioconcentration factors (ratio between tissue and sediment concentrations) of 5.7 and 12.0 were measured in Polychaete sp. and Capitella capitata(7). The BCF of fluoranthene in crayfish was determined to range between 1,520-3,510(1). A mean BCF of 76,696 was measured in the fresh-water amphipod Pontoporeia hoyi(8). When oysters were suspended in oil treated enclosures contaminated with fluoranthene dissolved in Prudhoe crude oil, the log BCF was 4.09 after 2 days exposure; after the oysters were transferred to clean water, depuration half-life was 5 days(9).

Reference: (1) Elder JF, Dresler PV; Environ Pollut 49: 117-32 (1988)
(2) Landrum PF et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 11: 1197-1208 (1992)
(3) Meador JP et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 143: 79-165 (1995)
(4) Tanacredl JT, Cardenas RR; Environ Sci Technol 25: 1453-61 (1991)

StringWithMarkup.String: Fluoranthene was detected in the soft-body tissue of the oyster Crassostrea virginica after 43 days incubation in the water of Pensacola Bay, FL at concns of 4 to 29 ug/kg(1). The mean fluoranthene concn in the amphipod Diporeia following 2 days exposure to sediment-sorbed polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons was 319, 145, and 120 nmol/g for sediments aged 3, 60, and 150 days, respectively(2). The half-life of fluoranthene in rainbow trout, clams, mussels, oysters, shrimp, and polycheates avgd 6, 3.3-8.4 days, 2.0-29.8 days, 5.9 days, 0.8 days, and 5.8 days, respectively(3). Mercenaria mercenaria, exposed in vitro for 48 hours to fluoranthene found in waste crankcase oil, did not significantly eliminate fluoranthene over a 45-day depuration period(4).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Brannon JM et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 51: 873-880 (1993)
(2) Brannon JM et al; Chemosphere 31: 3465-73 (1995)
(3) Gert-Jan De Maagd P et al; Polycyclic Aromat Compd 5: 219-24 (1994)
(4) He Y et al; Chemosphere 30: 141-50 (1995)
(5) Luers F, ten Hulscher ThEM; Chemosphere 33: 643-57 (1996)
(6) McGroddy SE, Farringtion JW; Environ Sci Technol 29: 1542-50 (1995)
(7) Sabljic A et al; Chemosphere 31: 4489-514 (1995)
(8) Szabo G et al; Chemosphere 21: 777-88 (1990)
(9) Szabo G et al; Chemosphere 21: 495-505 (1990)
(10) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: The measured log Koc for fluoranthene following 15 days of incubation in Oakland, Mixed and Red Hook sediments was determined to be 4.67 to 5.28, 4.72 to 5.47, and 4.47 to 4.62, respectively(1). The average log Koc value for fluoranthene in sediment from Brown's Lake, MS, and Hamlet City Lake, NC after six months incubation was reported to be 4.51 and 5.05, respectively(2). Sorption coefficients for fluoranthene obtained during 48 hour batch experiments using two lake sediments with an organic carbon content of 1.87 and 2.07%, and a high chemical concentration were 2600 and 2700, respectively(3). The log Koc values for fluoranthene on three soils from Germany and one from China were determined to be 4.81, 4.65, 4.80, and 4.83, respectively(4). The log Kdoc (partition coefficient for sorption to dissolved organic carbon) of fluoranthene was reported to range from 5.12 to 5.22; the log Kpoc (partition coefficient for sorption to particulate organic material was reported to be 5.4(5). Log Koc values reported in the literature were reported to be 4.79(6), 4.62(7), 4.74(8) and 4.87(9). According to a classification scheme(10), these log Koc values suggest that fluoranthene is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC).

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

Reference: (1) Shiu WY, Mackay D; J Chem Eng Data 42: 27-30 (1997)
(2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington,DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 15-1 to 15-29 (1990)
(3) Brannon JM et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 51: 873-880 (1993)
(4) USEPA; EXAMS II Computer Simulation (1987)

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for fluoranthene is 9.45X10-6 atm-cu(1). This Henry's Law constant indicates that fluoranthene is expected to volatilize from water surfaces(2). Based on this Henry's Law constant, the volatilization half-life from a model river (1 m deep, flowing 1 m/sec, wind velocity of 3 m/sec) is estimated as 4 days(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model lake (1 m deep, flowing 0.05 m/sec, wind velocity of 0.5 m/sec) is estimated as 46 days(SRC). Fluoranthene's Henry's Law constant(1) indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces may occur. However, adsorption is expected to attenuate the rate of volatilization from water and moist soils(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model pond was estimated as 17 years when adsorption was considered(3). Fluoranthene is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based on a vapor pressure of 9.22X10-6 mm Hg(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: Fluoranthene was detected in a coal tar contaminated aquifer in St Louis Park, MN(2). Fluoranthene concentrations as high as 10 ug/l have been detected in contaminated ground water in the Netherlands(3). Fluoranthene concentrations in groundwater in Germany ranged from 26.2-169.0 ng/L(2). Fluoranthene has been detected in raw water from the ground water supply in the Ohio River Basin(4). Fluoranthene was detected in 1 of 4 wells sampled in November down gradient from a wood preserving plant using creosote; these samples in July showed no PAH(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Fluoranthene was detected in drinking water of the Oporto, Portugal district with concentrations ranging from 0.0 to 6.3 ng/L(1). The mean concentration of fluoranthene detected in the drinking water in Ahmedabad, India was reported as 420.71 ng/L(2). Fluoranthene has been detected in Ottawa drinking water (Jan-Feb 1978) at concentrations of 0.55 and 1.9 ng/L(3). Fluoranthene was detected in finished water of 18 USA cities, was not detected in 11 cities (detection limit 0.1-0 ng/L), was detected at a concentration of 1-8.9 ng/L in 7 cities, and was detected at a concentration of 94.5 ng/L in Wheeling, WV(4). Finished water samples from Derwent, England yielded a fluoranthene concentration of 0.8 ng/L(4). Filtration, activated carbon treatment and chlorination remove considerable amounts of fluoranthene from drinking water. However distribution systems with asphalt or coal tar linings can contribute fluoranthene to the tap water. In one extreme case in Portland Oregon, the raw water had 4 ng/L and the distributed water 640 ng/L fluoranthene(4). Fluoranthene was detected in Nordic (Norway, Finalnd, Sweden) tap water at a concentration range of <0.58 to 24 ng/L(5). Fluoranthene was detected at >0.1 ug/L in finished water from 5 of 10 utilities in the Ohio River Basin(6). Fluoranthene was detected at mean concentrations of 7.2 to 112.9 ng/L in drinking water from 3 metropolitan areas of Taiwan(7).

Reference: (1) Ohio River Valley Water Sanit Comm; Assessment of Water Quality Conditions. Ohio River Mainstream 1978-9. Ohio River Valley Water Sanit Comm Cinncinnati OH p.T-52 (1980)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Fluoranthene was detected in 8 of 10 sites on Ohio River and tributaries at a concentration range of 15-258 ng/L(1). It was detcted, not quantified in the raw water of 7 of 9 utilities using surface water sources in the Ohio River Basin(2). Fluoranthene was monitored in 13 U.S. cities; it was not detected in raw water of 6 cities (detection limit 0.1-8 ng/L), detected at 4-25 ng/L in 5 cities, and reported at 114, 408 and 756 ng/L in Philadelphia PA, Pittsburg PA, and Wheeling WV, respectively(3).

Reference: (1) Broman D et al; Environ Sci Technol 25: 1850-64 (1991)
(2) Great Lakes Water Quality Board; Report on Great Lakes Water Quality p 195 (1983)
(3) Ko FC, Baker JE; Marine Chem 49: 171-88 (1995)

(6) Wan MT; J Environ Qual 23: 1297-1304 (1994)
(7) Ardag H et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 86: 221-225 (2011)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Water samples collected from three remote coastal and six offshore stations in the Baltic Sea contained fluoranthene concentrations ranging from 13 to 434 ng/cu m(1). Fluoranthene is listed as a contaminant of Great Lakes Ontario, Erie, Michigan and Superior including Lake St Clair(2). The avg concentration of fluoranthene in the surface water and bottom water of samples collected from October 1990 to August 1992 in the Chesapeake Bay was determined to be 0.98 and 1.29 ng/L, respectively(3). Water samples collected in 1992 at 9 sites along the San Jaoquin River, California were found to contain fluoranthene concentrations ranging from <1.0 to 3.0 ng/L(4). Fluoranthene was identified at a concentration range of <0.002 to 0.0125 ug/L in the surface waters of Alessandria District, southeastern Piedmont, Italy during the winter 1989-1990(5). The average concentration of fluoranthene in ditch water of farms, railway ditches with poles, and railway ditches without poles in Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada samples collected in 1990 and 1991 was determined to be 0.3, 2035 and 0.26 ug/L, respectively(9). Fluoranthene was detected at levels ranging from 0.2 to 0.9 ug/L in water samples collected at 8 locations of the Menderes River, Turkey (10).

StringWithMarkup.String: Those industries with mean raw or treated wastewater concentration of fluoranthene exceeding 500 ppb include: iron and steel manufacturing, metal finishing, organic chemicals and plastic manufacturing and timber products processing(1). Maximum raw wastewater concentration of 55, 35, 16, and 5 ppm have been observed in metal finishing, iron and steel manufacturing, timber products processing, and nonferrous metals manufacturing, respectively(1). Urban runoff from a commercial site contained 157.5 ng/L associated with particulates and 3.4 ng/L in soluble form. The fluoranthene was principally associated with particulates 125-250 um and < 45 um in size(2). Nationwide urban runoff program detected fluoranthene in 10% of the samples analyzed (51 catchments in 19 cities including 11 of the 18 major river basins in the contiguous USA), at concentration of 0.3-12 ug/L(3). Fluoranthene was found in unspecified waste water at 0.1-45 ug/L(4); domestic sewage effluent at 0.01 ug/L(5); effluent spray tower of municipal incinerator at 0.54 ug/L(5); effluent from sewage treatment plant in Norway at 0.126 and 0.515 ug/L in fall and spring dry period and at 0.082 and 1.66 ug/L after rain in fall and spring(6); and in effluent of tire manufacturing plant at 0.8 ug/L(7).

Reference: (1) Cretney J et al; Environ Sci Technol 19: 397-404 (1985)
(2) Eiceman GA et al; Anal Chem 51: 2343-50 (1979)

(5) Naes K et al; Sci Tot Environ 163: 93-106 (1995)

StringWithMarkup.String: Fluoranthene was identified in the air particulate matter collected from the lightly industrialized urban area of Christchurch, New Zealand, concentration unknown(1). Fluoranthene was identified as a stack emission and a component of fly ash from municipal waste incinerators(2). The open burning of rubber tires yielded 259 mg/kg chunk tire and 458 mg/kg shred tire of fluoranthene in the tire emissions(3). The concentration of fluoranthene in an effluent channel from a coking plant was determined to be 31.0 ug/g dry weight in sediment and 2.8 ug/L in the water effluent(4). Fluoranthene was detected in the wastewater effluent of two aluminum plants in Norway at concentrations of 600 ng/L and 212 ng/L(5).

Reference: (1) Jenkins BM et al; Environ Sci Technol 30: 2462-69 (1996)
(2) Nielsen PA, Jensen L; Chemosphere 23: 723-35 (1991)
(3) Tan YL et al; Atmos Environ 26A: 1177-81 (1992)

StringWithMarkup.String: Open burning of cereal grains and agricultural trees produced fluoranthene concentrations ranging from 0.17 to 7,316 ug/kg for cereal grains and 600 to 905 ug/kg for various woods(1). The fluoranthene concentration in the emission from furnaces fueled with cereal straw or wood chips was determined to range from 0.038 to 631.2 ug/cu m(2). Soot from a wood burning stove not equipped with a filter contained 2,300 ug/g of fluoranthene, and soot from a stove equipped with a filter contained 190 ug/g(3). The fine aerosol emission rate for fluoranthene from a frying hamburger (extra lean/regular), from a charbroiled hamburger (extra lean) and from a charbroiled hamburger (regular) was determined to be 0.13, 0.12, and 0.35 mg/kg, respectively(4).

Reference: (1) Rogge WF et al; Environ Sci Technol 27: 636-51 (1993)
(2) Rogge WF et al; Environ Sci Technol 27: 1892-1904 (1993)

StringWithMarkup.String: Fine aerosol emission rates for fluoranthene from noncatalyst automobiles, catalyst automobiles, and heavy-duty diesel trucks were determined to be 48.3, 2.0, and 13.0 ug/km, respectively(1). Fluoranthene was identified in tire wear particles, brake lining particles, and road dust particles at concentrations of 11.1, 0.69, and 6.9 ug/g of particle sample, respectively(2). Aerosol samples were collected systematically throughout a complete annual cycle (1982) at four urban sites in southern California. Ambient annual concentrations of fluoranthene ranged from 0.07 to 0.15 ng/cu-m(3). Fluoranthene was found in fine particulate abrasion products from green leaves at a concentration of 1.2 ug/g and from dead leaves at a concentration of 0.47 ug/g; samples collected were from trees characteristic of the Los Angeles, CA area(4). Fine particle emission rates for fluoranthene from a natural gas-fired water heater and a natural gas-fired space heater were determined. A HEPA-filtered dilution air sample emission rate for fluoranthene was determined to be 0.19 pg/kJ; the emission rate for fluoranthene through the first filter was determined to be 685.3 pg/kJ; the emission rate for fluoranthene through the backup filter was determined to be 251.7 pg/kJ(5). The concentration of fluoranthene in three engine fuels was determined to average 3.07 mg/L; the concentration of fluoranthene from particulate emission from a fuel-injected Otto engine was determined to average 2.05 ug/km(6). average emission rates of fluoranthene for diesel powered automobiles in Sweden were measured as 2.5 ug/km (particulate-phase) and 18 ug/km (vapor-phase), while the average emissions for unleaded gasoline powered automobiles were 17 ug/km (particulate-phase) and 5.6 ug/km (vapor-phase)(7). Fluoranthene was detected in diesel particulate at a concentration of 50 ug/g(8). Fluoranthene was identified in particulate matter from a spark-ignited engine and a diesel engine as having concentrations of 320 and 44 ug/g, respectively(9). It was detected in the Baltimore Harbor Tunnel at 93 ng/cu m(10).

Reference: (1) Benner BA Jr et al; Environ Sci Technol 24: 1418-27 (1990)
(2) Gressel MG et al; Appl Ind Hyg 3: 11-17 (1988)
(3) Khesina AY Environ Health Perspect 4: 49-53 (1994)
(4) Mi H-H et al; J Environ Sci Health A31: 1981-2003 (1996)
(5) Nelson EG et al; Environ Sci Technol 30: 1014-22 (1996)
(6) Ostman CE et al; pp. 729-44 in Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons: Chemistry, Characterization, and Carcinogenesis. 9th International Symposium. Columbus,OH: Battelle Press (1986)

StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of fluoranthene in smoke samples taken from intentionally burned Alberta Sweet Crude oil ranged from 37-740 ug/g(1). Emissions generated during the pouring, cooling, and shakeout of castings made with the evaporative pattern casting process contained fluoranthene at concentrations of 15 and 2 ug/kg for aluminum and iron castings, respectively(2). Soot extracts from GTD-5 and D-54A diesel engines were found to contain fluoranthene at mean concentrations of 7.7 and 32.8 ug/g, respectively(3). The average concentration of fluoranthene from a lead-free gasoline powered engine idling, at 40 km/hr, 80 km/hr, and 110 km/hr was determined to be 16.2, 14.7, 11.0, and 5.3 ug/cu-m, respectively; the average concentration of fluoranthene from a premium-leaded gasoline powered engine idling, 40 km/hr, 80 km/hr, and 110 km/hr was determined to be 9.7, 18.2, 6.26, and 1.14 ug/cu-m, respectively(4). The concentration of fluoranthene in both bulk coal tar and 1-year aged coal tar film has been determined to be 2,000 mg/kg(5). The concentration of fluoranthene in lubricating oil from three different vehicles fueled with gasoline, diesel, and gas was determined to be 64, 2.4, and 20 ppm, respectively(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Fluoranthene was reported in the following saples: lake sediment 0.42 ppb, river sediment 0.39 ppb, Buzzards Bay sed 0.110-0.790 ppb, Atlantic shelf sediment 0.0104-0.0167 ppb(1). Sediment from Port Angeles Harbor, WA, an area contaminated with fuel oil contained fluoranthene at 110-1100 ppb; 7.5-24 pbb was reported from Dungeness Bay, a nearby relatively pristane area(2). Dumwamish River sediment, WA contained 1700 ppb(3). Sediment from the Severn Estuary, England, a drainage system for industrial and domestic effluent, contained 0.5-5.2 ppm(4). The concentraion in sediment from mouth of Charles River, Boston extending into Massachusetts Bay decreases from 13000 ppb to 19 ppb with increasing distance from Boston. Concentrations of 19-120 ppb were reported in the Gulf of Maine and in the  Atlantic Ocean, beyond continental shelf, 4-11 ppb. A combustion source suggested(5). Lake Erie surficial sediment contained fluoranthene at 275-600 ppb 1-10 km from coal-fired power plant and in direction of current, and 70-110 ppb 1-10 km from power plant not in direction of current(6). Sediment concentrations from two remote Adirondack, NY lakes were as follows: Sagamore (depth cm/ppb): 0-4/460, 4-8/400, 8-80/3-81; Woods: sediment 0-4/1200, 4-8/320, 8-80/11-25(7). The compound was detected in Georges Bank surface sediment (various sites and seasons) at 1-130 ppb, including pyrene(8). Fluoranthene qas reported in an unspecified industrial river in USA from below chemical plant at 1-60 ppm in sediment although it was not detected in the river water(9).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Bottom sediments collected in the vicinity of a multi-well platform offshore of Matagorda, TX from May 1982 to November 1985 had an average fluoranthene concentration of 18.1 ppb(1). The median concentration of fluoranthene in 31 sediment cores collected during November and December 1991 at locations throughout the Arthur Kill, Hackensack River, and Passaic River were determined to be 2.40, 3.70, and 4.10 mg/kg, respectively(2). Two hundred and thirteen sediment samples from 58 sediment cores were collected throughout the Newark Bay Estuary, New Jersey during November/December 1991, December 1992, and March 1993; fluoranthene concentrations ranged from 0.27 to 530 mg/kg(3). Fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples collected from six stations in Hamilton Harbour, Ontario, Canada between April and September 1986(4). Sediment samples (12) of various parts of Lake Lagoda, Russia collected in June 1993 were found to contain fluoranthene ranging in concentrations from 1.3 to 140 ng/g(5). Fluoranthene was detected in surficial marine sediments collected from 20 sites within the Kitimat fjord system of British Columbia, Canada(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Surficial sediments from the Shatt Al-Arab River and the North-West Region of the Arabian Gulf collected from November 1979 to April 1980 were found to contain fluoranthene concentrations ranging from 0.02 to 8.96 ng/g(1). The concentration trend of fluoranthene in sediment cores from Lake Ketelmeer, Germany is 3.5 mg/kg in 1945, 4.5 mg/kg in 1965, and 1.5 mg/kg in 1985(2). Concentrations of fluoranthene in laminated sediments collected from the northern Baltic proper were, ug/g C (sediment layer, mm): 1.4 (0 to 1.8); 2.4 (1.8 to 3.6); 1.6 (3.6 to 5.4); 2.0 (7.2 to 9.0); 2.0 (10.8 to 12.6); 2.5 (16.2 to 18.0); 2.7 (21.6 to 23.4); 3.8 (27.0 to 28.8); 4.8 (32.4 to 34.2) and 4.7(37.8 to 39.6)(3). The concentration of fluoranthene in sediment collected in October 1986 from the Georges River estuary south of Sydney, Australia was determined to average 5.3 mg/kg(4). Sediments collected in Tokyo Bay in July and Aug 1973 contained fluoranthene at concentrations ranging from 0.01 to 0.39 mg/kg dry matter(5). Bed sediments collected in 1992 at 9 sites along the San Jaoquin River, California were found to contain fluoranthene concentrations ranging from 0.4 to 100 ng/L(6). The concentration of fluoranthene in the sediment of an uncontrolled hazardous waste dump near the Nervion River, North Spain, was determined to range from 0.8 to 380 ug/g(7). Fluoranthene was detected at a concentration of 20 ug/kg (dry wt) in surface sediments from the Cochin Backwaters wetlands in India(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: The distribution of fluoranthene in soil samples from various agricultural sites in Switzerland was determined to average 2.4 ug/kg dry weight(1). The average concentration of fluoranthene detected in soil samples collected from July 21-23, 1992 from 3 northeastern US cities was 3.05 mg/kg(2). Various sites at the Los Alamos National Laboratory were sampled; soil analysis revealed that the level of fluoranthene ranged from 0.68 to 3,200 mg/kg(3). Fluoranthene was present at 0.9 m depth 0.06 ppm, 1.8-6.1 m depth 0.01 ppm in soil cores 180 m downgradient from point where near surface groundwater was contaminated by coal tar derivates at a wood-treating plant at St Louis Park, MN that operated from 1918-1972(4). The level of fluoranthene in soil samples collected from the Rothamsted Experimental Station in southeast England since the mid-1800s up to the present show a concentration trend of 39, 45, 43, 37, 120, 190, 120, 210, and 120 ng/g in the years 1846, 1881, 1893, 1914, 1944, 1956, 1966, 1980, and 1986 respectively(5). Fluoranthene was detected in soil samples from the following locations near Lake Burley Griffin, Australia, ug/kg dry weight: Gininderra falls, 12; Civic, 105; and Queanbean, 159(6). Fluoranthene was identified but not quantified in soil samples from German forests(7). Fluoranthene was reported at  25-40 ppb in forest soil from the Bodensee area of Germany(8). Fluoranthene was detected in soils near incineration plants, industrial areas and high traffic roadside soils in Esbjerg, Denmark at levels ranging from 0.11 to 2.0 mg/kg(9). Concentrraions in soil from Nova Scotia soil (30 samples) ranged from 0.3-66 ppb, 8 ppb median(10). The mean concentration of floranthene in soils near Mexico City, Mexico were 1.00 to 1.87 mg/kg(11).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: During a high nitrogen oxide episode in Los Angeles, CA in Feb 1986, a fluoranthene concentration of 0.44-7.1 ng/cu m was measured during daylight and a fluoranthene concentration of 0.06-9.1 ng/cu m was measured at night-time(1). Fluoranthene concentrations in airborne particles sampled at four sites in an urban and industrialized area in the Netherlands ranged from 0.93 to 3.26(2). Fluoranthene was detected in (the particulate and vapor phases) air samples collected from Kosnica, Croatia in Feb and Aug of 1990 at mean concentrations of 150.0 and 20.6 ng/cu m, respectively(3). In a long-term air monitoring study of four urban United Kingdom areas sampled throughout 1991, the concentration of fluoranthene ranged from 12.5 to 33.5 ng/cu m(4). The average fluoranthene concentration in Birmingham, UK was 12.36 ng/cu m in the winter months and 2.11 ng/cu m during the summer months(5). Seasonal sampling at an urban site in Birmingham, England contained 12.4 ng/cu m fluoranthene in winter and 2.11 ng/cu m in summer; seasonal sampling at a rural site in South Kensington, England contained 0.41 ng/cu m fluoranthene in summer(6). Seventy samples of airborne particulates were sampled from two sites in Thessaloniki, Greece during a 1 year period starting in July 1987; the average fluoranthene concentration was determined to be 4.0 and 3.3 ng/cu m, respectively(7). Aerosol samples collected at six sites in Hong Kong during the winter months of 1993 were found to contain fluoranthene concentrations ranging from 136 to 2757 pg/cu m(8). The mean level of fluoranthene in air samples collected from Fairbanks, Alaska was 1.5 ng/cu m(9). Levels of fluoranthene ranged from 1.4 to 4.7 ng/cu m in the ambient air of Hagfors, Sweeden (10). Fluoranthene was detected in ambient air at 8 locations of the US in 2016 according to data contained in the EPA Air Quality System (AQS) database (11). The arithmetic means ranged from 0.44 to 1.86 ng/cu m at these 8 locations(11).

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR: The level of fluoranthene in 250 homes in Kenya using open fires to cook was determined to be a minimum of 30 ng/cu m and a max of 780 ng/cu m(1). A field study in which the indoor air of eight homes in Columbus, OH was monitored during the winter of 1986/1987 detected fluoranthene concentrations ranging from 3.0 to 23 ug/cu m(2). The level of fluoranthene in charcoal smoke alone and in smoke from charcoal grilling was determined to be 16 ug/kg and 25 ug/kg, respectively(3). The average concentration of fluoranthene in ten different homes in Columbus, OH ranged from 10.93 to 27.47 ng/cu m(4). The concentration of fluoranthene from open fire and unvented coal combustion in rural homes of Xuan Wei County, China, was determined to be 7.0 ug/cu m and 60.3 ug/m, respectively(5). The concentration of fluoranthene from unvented kerosene heater emissions in mobile homes was determined to be 1.6 ng/cu m with the heater off and 1.1 ng/m with the heater on(6). The level of exposure to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons from smoking kilns in Danish smokehouses was determined; the max fluoranthene concentration observed in 10 smokehouses was determined to be 460 ug/cu m(7). The level of fluoranthene in the homes of Ahmedabad, India using cattle dung, cattle dung/wood, and wood as cooking fuel was determined to be 267, 317, and 63 ng/cu m, respectively(8). Indoor air samples of fluoranthene measured in Fairbanks, Alaska had a mean level of 0.7 ng/ cu m (9). Fluoranthene levels of Swedish homes that used wood heating appliances ranged from 0.5 to 6.7 ng/cu m, while levels in homes that did not use wood heating ranged from 0.44 to 3.7 ng/cu m(10).

StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of fluoranthene in a grilled mesquite wood beef patty 70% lean was determined to be 103 ug/kg(1). StringWithMarkup.String: The level of fluoranthene contained in 5 shellfish and 14 types of fish along the coast of the Gulf of Naples, Italy was determined to range from not detected to 192 ug/kg(1). StringWithMarkup.String: Fluoranthene was identified in oligochaete worms and chironomid midges (in Lake Erie sediment 1-10 km from a coal-fired power plant) at concentrations of 10 ppb and 30-130 ppb, respectively(1). Fluoranthene was identified in the fur, biopsy, blood, liver, and feces of two colonies of Argentinian southern sea lions (Otaria flavescens) with concentrations of 47.57-57.91 ng/g in fur, 24.98-176.2 ng/g in biopsy, 64.35-92.88 in blood, 0.27-9.27 in the liver and 14.87-30.19 in the feces(2). The fluoranthene concentration found along the northern side of Kessels Road, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia was measured to be 5, 14, 6, 5, 14, and 52 ng/g in a slug, a beetle (Laxta granicollis), a millipede, a beetle (Platyzosteria nitida), an earthworm, and Casuarina littorina, respectively(3). Fluoranthene was identified in mayfly nymphs (Hexagenia limbata) exposed to untreated Hamilton Harbour, Ontario, Canada sediment for 21 days in concentrations ranging from 0.05 to 1.37 ug/g(4). Fluoranthene was detected in the plasma of sea turtles from the Canary Islands, Spain at a mean concentration of 0.03 ng/mL(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: The distribution of fluoranthene liquid manure and compost samples from various agricultural sites in Switzerland was determined to average 6.6 and 6.7 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(1). The concentration range of fluoranthene in new motor oil, used motor oil from petrol vehicles, used motor oil from diesel vehicles, used motor oil from diesel lorries, and used motor oil from diesel buses was determined to be 0.008-2.750, 3.4-109.0, 1.3-58.9, 0.18-2.90, and 0.40-2.70 ug/g, respectively(4). StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 2283 workers (none of these are female) were potentially exposed to fluoranthene in the US(1). Occupational exposure to fluoranthene may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where fluoranthene is produced. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to fluoranthene via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing fluoranthene(SRC).

The general population may be exposed to fluoranthene via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with vapors and food products containing fluoranthene(SRC).

StringWithMarkup.String: Human exposure to fluoranthene is from air, food, and water contaminated with products of combustion, with food being the most important route of exposure. Concentrations are highest in areas of high anthropogenic activity(1,2).

StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of gaseous and particulate fluoranthene in stationary samples from an aluminum plant in Norway was determined to be 6.71 and 7.58 ug/cu m(1). The mean concentration of fluoranthene in breathing zones of a needle coke plant was 0.98 ug/cu m(2). The average concentration of fluoranthene in worker's urine of aluminum plant workers was reported to be approximately 0.4 ug/mole creatinine(3). average exposure of workers to fluoranthene in the aluminum refinery, silicon carbide, and refractory brick industries is approx 0.66 ug/cu m(4). The concentration of fluoranthene at different worksites within two silicon carbide plants ranged from 17 to 63 ng/cu m and 66 to 1070 ng/cu m, respectively(5). The fluoranthene concentrations in a new coking plant in Finland were determined to range from 0.12-17.00 ug/cu m in 1988, 0.15-115.5 ug/cu m in 1989 and 0.15-15.92 ug/cu m in 1990(6).

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
